Subjunctive.rule: The subjunctive mood expresses doubt, desire, emotion, uncertainty, or hypothetical situations. It's used after certain triggers like expressions of doubt (dudar que), emotion (alegrarse que), desire (querer que), impersonal expressions (es necesario que), and certain conjunctions.
Subjunctive.structure: Trigger phrase + que + subjunctive verb form
formation: Present subjunctive: Take yo form, drop -o, add opposite endings (-ar verbs: -e, -es, -e, -emos, -éis, -en; -er/-ir verbs: -a, -as, -a, -amos, -áis, -an)
Irregulars: haya, sea, vaya, esté, dé, sepa, etc.
uses: After expressions of doubt: dudar que, no creer que, no pensar que
After expressions of emotion: alegrarse que, temer que, sorprender que
After expressions of desire/influence: querer que, esperar que, pedir que
After impersonal expressions: es importante que, es necesario que, es posible que
After certain conjunctions: aunque, para que, sin que, antes de que (future), después de que (future)
examples: Dudo que el gobierno suba los impuestos. (I doubt the government will raise taxes.)
Es importante que estudies para el examen. (It's important that you study for the exam.)
Espero que vengas a la fiesta. (I hope you come to the party.)
No creo que sea el mejor momento. (I don't think it's the best moment.)
important: 'Creo que' takes indicative, but 'no creo que' takes subjunctive
Subjunctive is used for pending/future actions with time conjunctions
Some conjunctions always require subjunctive (para que, sin que, a menos que)

Ser vs Estar.rule: SER is for permanent/essential characteristics, identity, origin, time, events, and possession. ESTAR is for temporary states, locations, conditions, emotions, and progressive actions.
formation: Ser: soy, eres, es, somos, sois, son
Estar: estoy, estás, está, estamos, estáis, están
uses: SER: Identity/profession (Soy médico), origin (Es de España), material/possession (Es de Juan), time/events (Es a las 8), characteristics (Es alto)
ESTAR: Location (Estoy en casa), temporary states (Está cansado), emotions (Estamos contentos), progressive (Estoy estudiando), resulting condition (La puerta está abierta)
examples: María es inteligente. (María is intelligent - permanent trait)
María está cansada hoy. (María is tired today - temporary state)
La reunión es en la oficina. (The meeting is in the office - event location)
Pedro está en la oficina. (Pedro is in the office - physical location)
Ser listo (to be clever) vs estar listo (to be ready)
Ser aburrido (to be boring) vs estar aburrido (to be bored)
important: Some adjectives change meaning with ser vs estar (listo, aburrido, bueno, malo, vivo, rico)
Location of events uses SER, physical location of people/things uses ESTAR
Progressive tenses always use ESTAR + gerund

Imperfecto vs Pretérito.rule: IMPERFECTO describes ongoing, habitual, or background actions in the past. PRETÉRITO describes completed, specific actions or events with definite beginning/end.
formation: Imperfect -ar: -aba, -abas, -aba, -ábamos, -abais, -aban
Imperfect -er/-ir: -ía, -ías, -ía, -íamos, -íais, -ían
Preterite -ar: -é, -aste, -ó, -amos, -asteis, -aron
Preterite -er/-ir: -í, -iste, -ió, -imos, -isteis, -ieron
uses: IMPERFECTO: Habitual actions (siempre jugaba), descriptions (era un día soleado), ongoing actions (mientras estudiaba), time/age (tenía 10 años), mental/emotional states (quería ir)
PRETÉRITO: Completed actions (jugué ayer), specific events (llegó a las 3), series of actions (entré, vi, compré), interrupting actions (sonó el teléfono), sudden changes (se cayó)
examples: Cuando era niño, vivía en Madrid. (When I was a child, I lived in Madrid - habitual/ongoing)
Ayer fui al supermercado. (Yesterday I went to the supermarket - completed)
Leía el periódico cuando llamaste. (I was reading the paper when you called - ongoing + interruption)
Antes de mudarse, mi abuela siempre contaba cuentos. (Before moving, my grandmother always told stories - habitual)
important: Time markers: Imperfect (siempre, generalmente, todos los días, mientras); Preterite (ayer, anoche, el año pasado, de repente)
In the same sentence, imperfect often sets the scene, preterite tells what happened
Verbs like saber, conocer, querer, poder change meaning in preterite

Para vs Por.rule: PARA indicates purpose, destination, deadline, or recipient. POR indicates cause, means, duration, exchange, or location of movement.
formation: Para: purpose, destination, deadline, recipient, opinion
Por: cause/reason, duration, exchange, movement through, means
uses: PARA: Purpose (estudio para aprender), destination (salgo para México), deadline (para el viernes), recipient (es para ti), opinion (para mí)
POR: Cause/reason (ganó por trabajar duro), duration (viví por dos años), exchange (pagué $5 por el café), movement through (pasé por el parque), means (hablé por teléfono)
examples: Trabajo para vivir. (I work in order to live - purpose)
Trabajo por la mañana. (I work during/in the morning - time period)
Este regalo es para María. (This gift is for María - recipient)
Por lo general, desayuno café. (Generally, I have coffee for breakfast - fixed expression)
Pagué 20 dólares por esta camisa. (I paid 20 dollars for this shirt - exchange)
Salgo para el aeropuerto. (I'm leaving for the airport - destination)
important: Fixed expressions with POR: por favor, por ejemplo, por fin, por lo general, por supuesto
Fixed expressions with PARA: para siempre, para colmo
Por + time period = duration; Para + specific time = deadline

Saber vs Conocer.rule: SABER is for factual knowledge, information, and skills (how to do something). CONOCER is for familiarity with people, places, and things.
formation: Saber: sé, sabes, sabe, sabemos, sabéis, saben
Conocer: conozco, conoces, conoce, conocemos, conocéis, conocen
uses: SABER: Facts/information (sé la capital), how to do (sé nadar), that-clauses (sé que es verdad), awareness (ya sé)
CONOCER: People (conozco a María), places (conozco París), things (conozco ese libro), experience (conozco su trabajo)
examples: ¿Sabes la capital de Australia? (Do you know the capital of Australia? - fact)
¿Conoces a mi hermano? (Do you know my brother? - person)
Sé tocar la guitarra. (I know how to play guitar - skill)
Conozco bien esta ciudad. (I know this city well - familiarity)
Sé que mañana va a llover. (I know that it will rain tomorrow - fact/information)
important: Saber + infinitive = to know how to do something
Saber + que = to know that (fact)
Conocer + person requires 'a' (personal a): Conozco a Juan
Cannot use 'conocer que' - only 'saber que'

Pedir vs Preguntar.rule: PEDIR is to ask for/request something or ask someone to do something. PREGUNTAR is to ask a question or inquire about information.
formation: Pedir: pido, pides, pide, pedimos, pedís, piden (stem-changing e→i)
Preguntar: pregunto, preguntas, pregunta, preguntamos, preguntáis, preguntan (regular)
uses: PEDIR: Request objects (pido un café), request actions (te pido que vengas), borrow/request (pedir prestado), order in restaurant (pedir el menú)
PREGUNTAR: Ask questions (pregunto la hora), inquire (preguntar por alguien), with si (pregunté si venía), question words (preguntar dónde/cuándo/cómo)
examples: Voy a pedir que me traigan el menú. (I'm going to request that they bring me the menu - request action)
Voy a preguntar si tienen opciones vegetarianas. (I'm going to ask if they have vegetarian options - ask question)
Le pedí el favor de ayudarme. (I asked him the favor of helping me - request)
Le pregunté cuánto costaba. (I asked him how much it cost - question)
Pedí un café. (I ordered/asked for a coffee - request object)
important: Pedir + noun = ask for/request (pido ayuda)
Pedir que + subjunctive = ask that someone do something
Preguntar + question word = ask + question (pregunté dónde, cuándo, cómo)
Preguntar si = ask if/whether

Llevar vs Traer.rule: LLEVAR is to take/carry away from the speaker's location. TRAER is to bring/carry toward the speaker's location. The key is direction relative to the speaker.
formation: Llevar: llevo, llevas, lleva, llevamos, lleváis, llevan (regular)
Traer: traigo, traes, trae, traemos, traéis, traen (irregular yo form)
uses: LLEVAR: Take away (llevo el libro a casa), carry (llevo mi mochila), take someone (llevo a mi hijo al colegio), transport (el río lleva agua al mar), wear (llevo jeans)
TRAER: Bring here (trae el libro cuando vengas), bring with (traje mi cámara), bring someone (trae a tu amigo)
examples: ¿Me puedes traer el libro cuando vengas? (Can you bring me the book when you come? - toward speaker)
Voy a llevar este paquete al correo. (I'm going to take this package to the post office - away from speaker)
La corriente lleva los barcos hacia el océano. (The current carries the boats toward the ocean - general movement)
La marea trae conchas a la orilla. (The tide brings shells to the shore - toward speaker's location)
El río lleva agua de las montañas hasta el mar. (The river carries water from mountains to sea - general movement)
important: Direction is key: llevar = away from speaker, traer = toward speaker
Llevar + time = to have been doing: Llevo dos años aquí (I've been here for two years)
Llevar also means 'to wear': Llevo una camisa azul

Conjunctions.rule: Conjunctions connect clauses and determine mood (indicative vs subjunctive). Some always require subjunctive, others depend on whether the action is future/uncertain or past/certain.
formation: Always subjunctive conjunctions: para que, sin que, a menos que, con tal de que, aunque (uncertainty), por más/mucho que
Depends on time: cuando, después de que, hasta que, en cuanto, tan pronto como (future=subjunctive, past=indicative)
uses: ALWAYS SUBJUNCTIVE: para que (so that), sin que (without), a menos que (unless), con tal de que (provided that), aunque (even if - uncertainty), por más/mucho que (no matter how much)
FUTURE=SUBJUNCTIVE, PAST=INDICATIVE: cuando (when), después de que (after), hasta que (until), en cuanto (as soon as), tan pronto como (as soon as)
examples: Te llamo cuando llegue. (I'll call you when I arrive - future, subjunctive)
Te llamé cuando llegué. (I called you when I arrived - past, indicative)
Estudiaré hasta que lo entienda. (I'll study until I understand it - future, subjunctive)
Estudié hasta que lo entendí. (I studied until I understood it - past, indicative)
Iremos al parque después de que deje de llover. (We'll go to the park after it stops raining - future, subjunctive)
Por más que intente, no consigo resolver esto. (No matter how much I try, I can't solve this - always subjunctive)
important: Time conjunctions: future/pending actions = subjunctive; past/habitual actions = indicative
Purpose conjunctions (para que, sin que) always use subjunctive
Concessive conjunctions (por más que, aunque) use subjunctive for uncertainty

Conditional Clauses.rule: Conditional clauses express hypothetical situations using 'si' (if). There are three types depending on the likelihood and time frame of the condition.
Conditional Clauses.structure: Type 1: Si + present indicative, present/future/imperative | Type 2: Si + imperfect subjunctive, conditional | Type 3: Si + pluperfect subjunctive, conditional perfect
formation: Type 1: Si + present (tienes), result in present/future/imperative
Type 2: Si + imperfect subjunctive (tuvieras), conditional (harías)
Type 3: Si + pluperfect subjunctive (hubieras tenido), conditional perfect (habrías hecho)
uses: TYPE 1: Real, possible, or likely conditions in present or future
TYPE 2: Hypothetical or contrary-to-fact situations in present or future
TYPE 3: Contrary-to-fact past conditions (what didn't happen)
examples: Si tienes dudas, pregunta. (If you have doubts, ask - Type 1: real/possible)
Si tuviera dinero, viajaría. (If I had money, I would travel - Type 2: hypothetical present)
Si hubiera estudiado, habría aprobado. (If I had studied, I would have passed - Type 3: contrary-to-fact past)
Si llueve, me quedo en casa. (If it rains, I'll stay home - Type 1)
Si fuera rico, compraría una casa. (If I were rich, I would buy a house - Type 2)
Si tuvieras más confianza, participarías más. (If you had more confidence, you would participate more - Type 2)
important: NEVER use future or conditional tense after 'si' - this is a MAJOR error
WRONG: Si tendrás / Si tendría → CORRECT: Si tienes (Type 1) / Si tuvieras (Type 2)
Type 1 uses present indicative after 'si', NOT future, even when talking about future events
Choose type based on likelihood: Type 1 = likely/possible, Type 2 = unlikely/hypothetical, Type 3 = past/impossible

Conditional Clauses Type 2.rule: Type 2 conditional sentences express hypothetical or contrary-to-fact situations in the present or future. See 'Conditional Clauses' for complete information on all three types.
formation: If-clause: imperfect subjunctive (-ra or -se endings)
Main clause: conditional tense (infinitive + ía, ías, ía, íamos, íais, ían)
uses: Hypothetical present situations
Contrary-to-fact present (opposite of reality)
Unlikely future scenarios
examples: Si tuviera más dinero, haría un viaje alrededor del mundo. (If I had more money, I would take a trip around the world)
Si fuera tú, no iría. (If I were you, I wouldn't go)
Si estudiaras más, aprobarías el examen. (If you studied more, you would pass the exam)
Si tuvieras más confianza, participarías más. (If you had more confidence, you would participate more)
important: This is covered in detail under 'Conditional Clauses' category
NEVER use conditional or future after 'si'
Type 2 expresses hypothetical situations, Type 1 expresses real possibilities

Imperative.rule: The imperative gives commands or instructions. It has different forms for affirmative and negative commands, and formal vs informal.
Imperative.structure: Verb in imperative form (+ pronouns if needed)
formation: Affirmative tú: Use 3rd person singular present for regulars (habla, come, escribe). Irregulars: ten, ven, pon, sal, haz, di, ve, sé
Negative tú: Use present subjunctive without final -s (no hables, no comas, no escribas)
Usted/Ustedes: Always use present subjunctive for both affirmative and negative (hable, coma, escriba / no hable, no coma)
uses: Give direct commands or instructions
Make requests (polite or direct)
Give directions
Offer suggestions or advice
examples: Habla más despacio. (Speak more slowly - tú affirmative)
No hables tan rápido. (Don't speak so fast - tú negative)
Hable usted con el director. (Speak with the director - usted affirmative)
Ten cuidado. (Be careful - tú irregular)
No tengas miedo. (Don't be afraid - tú negative)
Dime la verdad. (Tell me the truth - with pronoun attached)
No me digas. (Don't tell me - pronoun before verb)
important: With pronouns: Affirmative = attach to end (Dime, Házlo, Dáselo); Negative = place before verb (No me digas, No lo hagas)
8 irregular tú affirmative commands: ten, ven, pon, sal, haz, di, ve, sé
All negative commands use subjunctive forms
Usted/ustedes commands always use subjunctive (same form for affirmative and negative)

Reflexive Pronouns.rule: Reflexive pronouns (me, te, se, nos, os, se) indicate the subject performs an action on itself, express spontaneous/natural processes, or are required with certain verbs.
Reflexive Pronouns.structure: Reflexive pronoun + verb (or verb + reflexive pronoun attached)
formation: Reflexive pronouns: me, te, se, nos, os, se
Position: Before conjugated verb or attached to infinitive/gerund/affirmative command
uses: TRUE REFLEXIVE: Subject does action to itself (me lavo, se peina, nos vestimos)
RECIPROCAL: Each other (se aman, nos vemos)
CHANGE MEANING: Some verbs change meaning with se (dormir→dormirse, ir→irse, llamar→llamarse)
SPONTANEOUS: Natural processes or unplanned events (se rompió, se derritió, se cayó)
ALWAYS REFLEXIVE: Some verbs always used reflexively (quejarse, arrepentirse, atreverse)
examples: Me lavo las manos. (I wash my hands - true reflexive)
Se aman. (They love each other - reciprocal)
El hielo se derritió con el calor. (The ice melted with the heat - spontaneous/natural process)
Se rompió el vaso. (The glass broke - unplanned event)
Me llamo María. (My name is María / I'm called María - always reflexive)
Nos vemos mañana. (We'll see each other tomorrow - reciprocal)
important: Position: Me lavo (present) / Voy a lavarme or Me voy a lavar (with infinitive) / Estoy lavándome or Me estoy lavando (with gerund)
Some common always-reflexive verbs: quejarse, arrepentirse, atreverse, acordarse, darse cuenta
Spontaneous se often indicates natural processes: se cayó, se rompió, se acabó, se derritió

Object Pronouns.rule: Direct object pronouns replace the direct object (what/who receives the action). Indirect object pronouns replace the indirect object (to/for whom). Order: Indirect + Direct + Verb.
Object Pronouns.structure: IOP + DOP + verb (or verb + IOP + DOP attached)
formation: Direct pronouns: me, te, lo/la, nos, os, los/las
Indirect pronouns: me, te, le, nos, os, les
When both start with 'l': le/les becomes se → se lo, se la, se los, se las
uses: Direct pronouns replace direct objects (¿El libro? Lo leí)
Indirect pronouns replace indirect objects (Le di el regalo = I gave the gift to him/her)
Both together: Indirect before direct (Me lo dio = He gave it to me)
Le/les becomes 'se' before lo/la/los/las (Se lo di = I gave it to him/her/them)
examples: ¿La carta? Ya la escribí. (The letter? I already wrote it - direct object)
¿Le diste el regalo a María? Sí, se lo di. (Did you give the gift to María? Yes, I gave it to her - both objects)
No me lo digas. (Don't tell it to me - both pronouns before negative command)
Voy a comprártelo. (I'm going to buy it for you - both attached to infinitive)
Estoy dándotelo. (I'm giving it to you - both attached to gerund)
important: Order is ALWAYS: Indirect + Direct + Verb (or attached in same order)
Le/les + lo/la/los/las = se lo/la/los/las (never le lo)
With infinitive/gerund: can attach or place before conjugated verb (Voy a dártelo = Te lo voy a dar)
With commands: Affirmative = attach (Dámelo), Negative = before (No me lo des)

Passive Voice.rule: The passive voice emphasizes the action or the recipient rather than the doer. Spanish has two main passive constructions: ser + past participle (emphasizes agent) and se passive (agent unknown/unimportant).
Passive Voice.structure: Ser passive: Subject + ser + past participle (+ por + agent) | Se passive: Se + verb + subject
formation: Ser passive: ser (conjugated) + past participle (agrees with subject in gender/number)
Se passive: se + verb (3rd person, agrees with subject in number)
uses: SER PASSIVE: When the agent (doer) is mentioned or emphasized
SE PASSIVE: When the agent is unknown or not important
examples: Los resultados serán publicados por la universidad. (The results will be published by the university - ser passive, agent mentioned)
Los estudiantes fueron invitados a la conferencia. (The students were invited to the conference - ser passive)
Se venden casas. (Houses are sold / Houses for sale - se passive, agent unknown)
Se habla español. (Spanish is spoken - se passive)
Aquí se come bien. (One eats well here / The food is good here - se passive)
important: Past participle in ser passive agrees with subject: fueron invitados (masculine plural)
Se passive verb agrees with subject: Se vende casa (singular) vs Se venden casas (plural)
Ser passive is less common in Spanish than in English; se passive is preferred

Present Perfect vs Preterite.rule: PRESENT PERFECT (haber + past participle) connects past to present or describes recent actions. PRETERITE describes completed actions at specific past times.
Present Perfect vs Preterite.structure: Present perfect: haber (present) + past participle | Preterite: preterite verb form
formation: Present perfect: he, has, ha, hemos, habéis, han + past participle (-ado, -ido)
Preterite: See 'Imperfecto vs Pretérito' for preterite formation
uses: PRESENT PERFECT: Recent past, life experience (ever), actions affecting present, unfinished time periods (hoy, esta semana)
PRETERITE: Completed past actions, specific time references, finished time periods (ayer, la semana pasada)
examples: He estudiado toda la mañana. (I've studied all morning - still morning or recent)
Estudié toda la mañana. (I studied all morning - morning is over)
¿Has visto esta película? (Have you seen this movie? - ever in your life)
¿Viste la película anoche? (Did you see the movie last night? - specific past time)
Hoy he trabajado mucho. (Today I've worked a lot - unfinished time period)
Ayer trabajé mucho. (Yesterday I worked a lot - finished time period)
important: Time markers: Present perfect (hoy, esta semana, ya, todavía no, nunca, alguna vez); Preterite (ayer, anoche, la semana pasada, en 2020)
In Spain: Present perfect for recent past is very common
In Latin America: Preterite often used even for recent past
Present perfect connects to present, preterite is disconnected from present

Possessives.rule: Possessive adjectives (mi, tu, su, etc.) go before nouns without articles. Possessive pronouns (mío, tuyo, suyo, etc.) replace nouns and can use articles.
Possessives.structure: Short form (before noun): possessive + noun | Long form (after noun or alone): article + noun + possessive OR article + possessive
formation: Short forms (before noun): mi/mis, tu/tus, su/sus, nuestro/a/os/as, vuestro/a/os/as
Long forms (after noun/alone): mío/a/os/as, tuyo/a/os/as, suyo/a/os/as, nuestro/a/os/as, vuestro/a/os/as
uses: SHORT FORMS: Before nouns, no article (mi casa, tus libros, nuestra familia)
LONG FORMS: After nouns (un amigo mío), standing alone as pronouns (El libro es mío), with articles (la mía, los tuyos)
examples: Mi casa es grande. (My house is big - short form before noun)
Un amigo mío vive aquí. (A friend of mine lives here - long form after noun)
El libro es mío. (The book is mine - long form as pronoun)
Esta casa es la nuestra. (This house is ours - long form with article)
Tus ideas son mejores que las mías. (Your ideas are better than mine - comparison)
important: Su/suyo is ambiguous (his/her/your/their) - clarify with: de él (his), de ella (hers), de usted (yours), de ellos (theirs)
Short forms never use articles: mi casa (NOT la mi casa)
Long forms agree in gender and number with the thing possessed
After ser, use long form without article: Es mío (NOT Es el mío)

Relative Pronouns.rule: Relative pronouns connect clauses and refer back to a noun (antecedent). Choose based on the antecedent and function in the clause.
formation: Que: most common, for people or things
Quien/quienes: only for people, after prepositions or in non-defining clauses
El/la/los/las que: more specific, agrees with antecedent
Lo que: neuter, for abstract ideas or clauses
Cuyo/a/os/as: possessive, agrees with thing possessed
uses: QUE: People or things as subject or object (el libro que leí, la mujer que vive aquí)
QUIEN/ES: People only, after prepositions (la persona con quien hablé) or non-defining clauses
EL/LA/LOS/LAS QUE: More specific, after prepositions (la casa en la que vivo)
LO QUE: Abstract ideas, concepts, entire clauses (lo que me preocupa)
CUYO: Possessive - whose (el autor cuyo libro leí)
examples: El libro que leí es interesante. (The book that I read is interesting - que for thing as object)
La persona con quien hablé es amable. (The person with whom I spoke is kind - quien after preposition)
Lo que me preocupa es tu salud. (What worries me is your health - lo que for abstract idea)
El autor cuyo libro leí ganó un premio. (The author whose book I read won a prize - cuyo possessive)
La casa en la que vivo es antigua. (The house in which I live is old - el que after preposition)
important: Que is most common and used for both people and things
After prepositions with people, use quien/quienes
Lo que always refers to abstract ideas or concepts, not specific nouns
Cuyo agrees with the thing possessed, not the possessor

Adverbs.rule: Most Spanish adverbs are formed by adding -mente to the feminine singular form of an adjective. They modify verbs, adjectives, or other adverbs.
formation: Adjective ends in -o: use feminine form + -mente (rápido → rápida → rápidamente)
Adjective ends in -e or consonant: add -mente directly (fácil → fácilmente)
Written accent maintained (rápido → rápidamente keeps accent)
Multiple adverbs: only last takes -mente (clara y directamente)
uses: Modify verbs: how an action is done (habla claramente)
Modify adjectives: degree or manner (muy grande, bastante caro)
Modify other adverbs: degree (muy rápidamente)
examples: El político habló honestamente. (The politician spoke honestly - modifies verb)
Habló clara y directamente. (He spoke clearly and directly - multiple adverbs, only last has -mente)
Actuó rápida y eficientemente. (She acted quickly and efficiently - multiple adverbs)
Trabaja lenta pero cuidadosamente. (He works slowly but carefully)
Respondió muy rápidamente. (She answered very quickly - adverb modifying adverb)
important: When 2+ adverbs together, only LAST takes -mente; others use feminine adjective form
Irregular adverbs: bueno→bien, malo→mal (not buenamente, malamente)
Position: usually after verb, can be at beginning for emphasis
Some adjectives used as adverbs without -mente: hablar claro, trabajar duro

Verbs like Gustar.rule: Verbs like gustar use a reverse construction: the thing liked is the subject, and the person who likes is the indirect object. The verb agrees with the subject (thing liked).
formation: Indirect object pronouns: me, te, le, nos, os, les
Verb agrees with subject: singular subject = singular verb; plural subject = plural verb
Common verbs: gustar, encantar, interesar, importar, molestar, faltar, quedar, doler, fascinar, aburrir
uses: Express likes/dislikes (gustar, encantar)
Express interest (interesar, fascinar)
Express importance (importar)
Express bothering (molestar, aburrir)
Express lacking (faltar, quedar)
Express pain (doler)
examples: Me gusta la música. (I like music - singular subject, singular verb)
Me gustan las películas. (I like movies - plural subject, plural verb)
A María le encanta bailar. (María loves to dance - infinitive subject)
Nos interesan los deportes. (Sports interest us / We're interested in sports - plural subject)
¿Te duele la cabeza? (Does your head hurt? - singular subject)
Me faltan dos dólares. (I'm missing two dollars - plural subject)
important: Structure: IOP + verb + subject (thing/person causing the feeling)
Verb agrees with subject (what's liked/interesting/hurting), NOT with person
Use 'a + person' to clarify or emphasize: A mí me gusta, A ti te gusta
With infinitives, use singular verb: Me gusta bailar y cantar

Time Expressions.rule: Spanish has specific expressions and constructions for talking about time, including 'acabar de' (to have just), 'hace... que' (ago/for), 'llevar' (to have been), and others.
formation: Acabar de + infinitive = to have just done
Hace + time + que + present = has been doing for (time)
Hace + time = ago
Llevar + time + gerund = to have been doing for (time)
Desde hace + time = for/since
uses: ACABAR DE: Recent completion (acabo de llegar)
HACE... QUE (present): Duration of ongoing action (hace dos años que vivo aquí)
HACE (preterite): Time ago (llegó hace dos horas)
LLEVAR: Duration with gerund (llevo tres años estudiando)
YA: Already/now (ya terminé, ya no vive aquí)
TODAVÍA: Still/yet (todavía estoy trabajando, todavía no he terminado)
examples: Acabo de llegar. (I have just arrived - acabar de)
Lo vi hace tres días. (I saw him three days ago - hace + preterite)
Hace dos años que vivo aquí. (I've been living here for two years - hace...que + present)
Llevo tres años estudiando español. (I've been studying Spanish for three years - llevar + gerund)
Vivo aquí desde hace cinco años. (I've been living here for five years - desde hace)
Ya terminé. (I already finished - ya)
Todavía no he terminado. (I still haven't finished - todavía no)
important: Acabar de + infinitive (never participle): acabo de llegar (NOT acabo de llegado)
Hace with present tense = for (duration), hace with preterite = ago
Ya = already (affirmative), ya no = no longer
Todavía = still (affirmative), todavía no = not yet

Conditional Tense.rule: The conditional expresses what would happen under certain conditions, polite requests, probability in the past, or future from a past perspective.
formation: Regular: Infinitive + ía, ías, ía, íamos, íais, ían
Same stem changes as future: hacer→haría, decir→diría, poder→podría, tener→tendría, poner→pondría, salir→saldría, venir→vendría, querer→querría, saber→sabría, haber→habría
uses: Hypothetical situations (Si tuviera dinero, viajaría)
Polite requests (¿Podrías ayudarme?)
Probability in the past (Serían las tres cuando llegó)
Future from past perspective (Dijo que vendría)
Giving advice (Yo no haría eso)
examples: Si tuviera más dinero, haría un viaje alrededor del mundo. (If I had more money, I would take a trip around the world - hypothetical)
¿Te gustaría bailar? (Would you like to dance? - polite request)
Me gustaría un café, por favor. (I would like a coffee, please - polite)
Serían las diez cuando llamó. (It must have been ten when he called - probability in past)
Dijo que vendría mañana. (He said he would come tomorrow - future in past)
important: Used in Type 2 conditionals with si + imperfect subjunctive
Never use conditional after 'si' in conditional sentences
Same irregular stems as future tense
More polite than present for requests: ¿Podrías...? vs ¿Puedes...?

Future Simple.rule: The future tense expresses what will happen, probability in the present, or predictions. It has regular and irregular forms.
formation: Regular: Infinitive + é, ás, á, emos, éis, án
Irregular stems (same as conditional): hacer→haré, decir→diré, poder→podré, tener→tendré, poner→pondré, salir→saldré, venir→vendré, querer→querré, saber→sabré, haber→habrá
uses: Future actions (Mañana estudiaré)
Probability/conjecture in present (Serán las tres = It must be 3 o'clock)
Promises (Te lo haré)
Predictions (Lloverá mañana)
examples: El próximo año viajaré a España. (Next year I will travel to Spain - future action)
¿Dónde estará Juan? (Where could Juan be? - probability/conjecture)
Te llamaré más tarde. (I'll call you later - promise)
Mañana lloverá. (It will rain tomorrow - prediction)
Los resultados serán publicados el próximo mes. (The results will be published next month)
important: In conversation, 'ir a + infinitive' is more common than future tense
Probability in present: future tense (¿Dónde estará? = Where could he be?)
Same irregular stems as conditional
Don't use future after 'si' in conditional sentences

Past Perfect.rule: The past perfect (pluperfect) expresses an action that occurred before another past action. It uses the imperfect of haber + past participle.
formation: Imperfect of haber: había, habías, había, habíamos, habíais, habían
Past participles: -ado (for -ar verbs), -ido (for -er/-ir verbs)
Irregular participles: hecho, dicho, visto, escrito, abierto, muerto, puesto, vuelto, roto, etc.
uses: Action before another past action (Cuando llegué, ya había salido)
Past experience before a past time (Nunca había estado en París)
Unrealized past action (Había planeado ir, pero no pude)
examples: Ya había comido cuando me invitaron. (I had already eaten when they invited me - action before another past action)
Nunca había visto algo así. (I had never seen anything like that - past experience)
Cuando llegamos, la película ya había empezado. (When we arrived, the movie had already started - earlier action)
Había planeado visitarte, pero me enfermé. (I had planned to visit you, but I got sick - unrealized past)
important: Shows sequence: past perfect for earlier action, preterite/imperfect for later action
Often used with 'ya' (already), 'todavía' (still/yet), 'nunca' (never)
Distinguishes which of two past actions happened first

Comparatives and Superlatives.rule: Comparatives compare two things using más/menos... que or tan... como. Superlatives express the highest degree using el/la/los/las más/menos.
Comparatives and Superlatives.structure: Comparative: más/menos/tan + adj/adv + que/como | Superlative: el/la/los/las + más/menos + adj + de
formation: Comparative equality: tan + adj/adv + como
Comparative inequality: más/menos + adj/adv + que
Superlative: el/la/los/las + más/menos + adj + de
Irregular comparatives: bueno→mejor, malo→peor, grande→mayor, pequeño→menor, mucho→más, poco→menos
uses: EQUALITY: Compare equal things (tan alto como)
INEQUALITY: Compare unequal things (más alto que, menos alto que)
SUPERLATIVE: Express highest/lowest degree (el más alto de)
ABSOLUTE SUPERLATIVE: Very/extremely (altísimo)
examples: Es tan alto como su hermano. (He's as tall as his brother - equality)
Es más inteligente que yo. (He's more intelligent than me - inequality)
Es el más alto de la clase. (He's the tallest in the class - superlative)
Es el mejor estudiante del colegio. (He's the best student in the school - irregular superlative)
La película es interesantísima. (The movie is extremely interesting - absolute superlative)
important: Use 'de' not 'en' after superlative: el mejor del mundo
Irregular comparatives don't use más: mejor (NOT más bueno), peor (NOT más malo)
Absolute superlative: -ísimo/a/os/as (drop final vowel, add -ísimo)
Some spelling changes in -ísimo: rico→riquísimo, largo→larguísimo

Present Simple vs Present Continuous.rule: PRESENT SIMPLE expresses habitual actions, general truths, and states. PRESENT CONTINUOUS (estar + gerund) expresses actions in progress right now or temporary situations.
Present Simple vs Present Continuous.structure: Present simple: conjugated verb | Present continuous: estar + gerund (-ando/-iendo)
formation: Present simple: regular conjugation (-o, -as, -a, -amos, -áis, -an for -ar verbs)
Present continuous: estar + gerund (-ar→-ando, -er/-ir→-iendo)
Gerund irregulars: leer→leyendo, dormir→durmiendo, pedir→pidiendo, ir→yendo
uses: PRESENT SIMPLE: Habitual actions (trabajo todos los días), general truths (el sol sale por el este), states (vivo en Madrid), scheduled future (el tren sale a las 3)
PRESENT CONTINUOUS: Action in progress now (estoy comiendo), temporary situation (estoy trabajando en un proyecto), changing situation (está lloviendo)
examples: Como pan todos los días. (I eat bread every day - habitual, present simple)
Estoy comiendo pan ahora. (I'm eating bread now - in progress, present continuous)
¿Qué haces? - Soy profesor. (What do you do? - I'm a teacher - profession, present simple)
¿Qué estás haciendo? - Estoy estudiando. (What are you doing? - I'm studying - right now, present continuous)
Vivo en Madrid. (I live in Madrid - state, present simple)
Estoy viviendo en un hotel temporalmente. (I'm living in a hotel temporarily - temporary, present continuous)
important: State verbs rarely use continuous: ser, estar, tener, saber, conocer
Spanish uses simple present more than English (I'm going tomorrow = Voy mañana)
Gerund stem changes: e→i (servir→sirviendo), o→u (dormir→durmiendo)
Progressive emphasizes action in progress; simple present is more general

Se Constructions.rule: The pronoun 'se' has multiple uses: impersonal (one/people), passive (when agent not specified), accidental (unplanned events), and reciprocal (each other).
Se Constructions.structure: Various depending on type: Impersonal: se + 3rd sing | Passive: se + verb + subject | Accidental: se + IOP + verb | Reciprocal: se + plural verb
formation: Impersonal se: se + 3rd person singular verb
Passive se: se + verb (agrees with subject)
Accidental se: se + indirect object pronoun + verb
Reciprocal se: se + plural verb (requires plural subject)
uses: IMPERSONAL: Express 'one/people/they' as general subject (se habla español)
PASSIVE: Passive meaning when agent not specified (se vende casa)
ACCIDENTAL: Unplanned or accidental events (se me cayó)
RECIPROCAL: Each other (requires plural subject) (se aman)
examples: Se habla español aquí. (Spanish is spoken here / One speaks Spanish here - impersonal)
¿Cómo se dice 'hello' en español? (How do you say 'hello' in Spanish? - impersonal)
Se venden casas. (Houses for sale / Houses are sold - passive)
Se construyeron muchas casas. (Many houses were built - passive)
Se me cayó el vaso. (I dropped the glass / The glass fell from me - accidental)
Se nos olvidó la tarea. (We forgot the homework - accidental)
Se aman. (They love each other - reciprocal)
Nos vemos mañana. (We'll see each other tomorrow - reciprocal)
important: Impersonal se is always 3rd person singular, passive se agrees with subject
Accidental se removes blame: se me cayó (it fell from me) vs lo caí (I dropped it)
Common accidental se verbs: caerse, olvidarse, perderse, romperse, quemarse
Reciprocal se requires plural subject: se aman (they love each other)

Todavía vs Ya.rule: TODAVÍA (still/yet) indicates continuation or non-completion. YA (already/anymore/now) indicates completion or change of state.
formation: Todavía = still (affirmative), yet (negative)
Todavía no = not yet
Ya = already (affirmative), now/right now (emphasis)
Ya no = no longer, not anymore
uses: TODAVÍA (affirmative): Still (continuation) - todavía estoy trabajando
TODAVÍA NO: Not yet (expected to change) - todavía no he terminado
YA (affirmative): Already (completion) - ya terminé
YA NO: No longer (was true, now false) - ya no vive aquí
YA (emphasis): Now, right now - ¡Hazlo ya!
examples: ¿Todavía vives en Madrid? (Do you still live in Madrid? - continuation)
Sí, todavía. (Yes, still - affirmative)
Todavía no ha llegado. (He hasn't arrived yet - not yet, but expected)
¿Ya terminaste? (Did you already finish? - completion)
Sí, ya. (Yes, already - affirmative)
Ya no fumo. (I don't smoke anymore - was true, now false)
¡Ya voy! (I'm coming! - right now/emphasis)
important: Todavía = expecting continuation; Ya = expecting completion or change
Todavía no = not yet (expecting yes later)
Ya no = no longer (was yes, now no)
Ya can mean 'already', 'now', or 'anymore' depending on context
Both can be used with various tenses

Quantifiers.rule: Quantifiers indicate amount or number. They include algún/ningún, todo, mucho/poco, varios, and others. Some change form based on gender/number.
formation: Algún/alguno/alguna/algunos/algunas (some/any)
Ningún/ninguno/ninguna (no/none/not any - usually singular)
Todo/toda/todos/todas (all/every/whole)
Mucho/mucha/muchos/muchas (much/many)
Poco/poca/pocos/pocas (little/few)
Otro/otra/otros/otras (other/another - no article)
Varios/varias (several)
uses: ALGÚN/NINGÚN: Some/any (affirmative/questions) vs no/none (negative)
TODO: All/every/whole (usually with article)
MUCHO/POCO: Much/many vs little/few
OTRO: Other/another (never with article)
VARIOS: Several
examples: ¿Tienes algún libro? (Do you have any book? - question)
Tengo algunos amigos aquí. (I have some friends here - affirmative)
No tengo ningún libro. (I don't have any book - negative)
Todo el día (All day / The whole day - with article)
Todos los días (Every day - with article)
Tengo mucho tiempo. (I have a lot of time - singular)
Hay muchas personas. (There are many people - plural)
Dame otro café. (Give me another coffee - no article with otro)
important: Algún/ningún before masculine singular noun; alguno/ninguno when alone
Ningún usually singular even when English uses plural
Todo usually requires article: todo el día, todos los días
Otro NEVER uses article: otro libro (NOT un otro libro)
Mucho/poco agree in gender and number with noun

Quedar.rule: QUEDAR has multiple meanings: to remain/stay, to have left (gustar-type), to fit (clothing), to arrange to meet, and to be located.
formation: Quedar: quedo, quedas, queda, quedamos, quedáis, quedan (regular)
Quedarse (reflexive): me quedo, te quedas, se queda, nos quedamos, os quedáis, se quedan
uses: TO REMAIN/STAY: Me quedé en casa (I stayed at home - reflexive)
TO HAVE LEFT: Me quedan dos días (I have two days left - gustar-type)
TO FIT (clothing): La camisa me queda bien (The shirt fits me well)
TO ARRANGE TO MEET: Quedamos a las 5 (We're meeting at 5)
TO BE LOCATED: El hotel queda cerca (The hotel is located nearby)
examples: Me quedé en casa todo el día. (I stayed at home all day - reflexive)
Me queda un dólar. (I have one dollar left - gustar-type, singular subject)
Me quedan tres días. (I have three days left - gustar-type, plural subject)
El vestido te queda bien. (The dress fits you well - clothing)
¿Quedamos a las 8? (Shall we meet at 8? - arrange to meet)
La farmacia queda en la esquina. (The pharmacy is located on the corner - location)
important: Quedarse = to stay/remain (reflexive); quedar = other meanings (non-reflexive)
With clothing: bien (fits well), mal (fits poorly), grande/pequeño (too big/small)
Quedar + left uses gustar structure: IOP + quedar + subject
Quedarse con = to keep (Quédate con el cambio = Keep the change)

Ningún vs Ninguno.rule: NINGÚN is used before masculine singular nouns. NINGUNO is used when standing alone or after the noun. Both mean 'no/none/not any'.
Ningún vs Ninguno.structure: Ningún + masculine singular noun | Ninguno (alone or after noun) | Ninguna (feminine)
formation: Ningún: before masculine singular noun only
Ninguno: standing alone, after noun (rare), or in phrases like 'ninguno de'
Ninguna: feminine form (before noun or alone)
uses: BEFORE masculine singular noun: ningún libro, ningún problema
STANDING ALONE: ¿Cuál? Ninguno. (Which one? None.)
WITH 'DE': Ninguno de ellos (None of them)
FEMININE: ninguna solución, ninguna de ellas
examples: No tengo ningún libro. (I don't have any book - before masculine noun)
¿Tienes libros? No, no tengo ninguno. (Do you have books? No, I don't have any - standing alone)
Ninguno de los estudiantes vino. (None of the students came - with 'de')
No hay ninguna solución. (There's no solution - feminine)
¿Cuál prefieres? Ninguno. (Which do you prefer? None - standing alone)
important: Usually used in singular even when English uses plural
Part of negative words: ningún, ninguno, ninguna, nadie, nada, nunca, tampoco
Double negative is standard in Spanish: No tengo ninguno (lit. 'I don't have none')
After 'sin': sin ningún problema (without any problem - no article)

Superlatives.rule: Superlatives express the extreme degree of a quality. Relative superlatives use el/la/los/las + más/menos + adjective. Absolute superlatives use -ísimo.
Superlatives.structure: Relative: el/la/los/las + más/menos + adj + de | Absolute: adj stem + ísimo/a/os/as
formation: Relative superlative: article + más/menos + adjective + de
Absolute superlative: drop final vowel, add -ísimo/a/os/as
Spelling changes in absolute: c→qu (rico→riquísimo), g→gu (largo→larguísimo), z→c (feliz→felicísimo)
uses: RELATIVE SUPERLATIVE: Compare one thing to a group (the most/least...)
ABSOLUTE SUPERLATIVE: Express very/extremely without comparison
IRREGULAR SUPERLATIVES: mejor (best), peor (worst), mayor (biggest/oldest), menor (smallest/youngest)
examples: Es el estudiante más inteligente de la clase. (He's the most intelligent student in the class - relative)
Son las películas menos interesantes del año. (They're the least interesting movies of the year - relative)
Es la ciudad más grande del país. (It's the biggest city in the country - relative)
Es el mejor estudiante del colegio. (He's the best student in the school - irregular)
La película es interesantísima. (The movie is extremely interesting - absolute)
Estoy cansadísimo. (I'm very tired - absolute)
important: Use 'de' not 'en' after superlative: el mejor del mundo (NOT en el mundo)
Superlative adjective can go before or after noun
Article agrees with noun: la más alta, los más altos
Absolute superlative doesn't compare, just intensifies: muy interesante = interesantísimo

Algún vs Ningún.rule: ALGÚN/ALGUNO means 'some/any' and is used in affirmative and interrogative sentences. NINGÚN/NINGUNO means 'no/none/not any' and is used in negative sentences.
formation: Algún: before masculine singular noun
Alguno: standing alone or after noun
Alguna/algunos/algunas: feminine/plural forms
Ningún: before masculine singular noun
Ninguno: standing alone or after noun
Ninguna: feminine form
uses: ALGÚN: In questions and affirmative sentences (some/any)
NINGÚN: In negative sentences (no/none/not any)
Both usually appear before noun, but can stand alone
examples: ¿Hay algún mensaje? (Is there any message? - question)
Algunos estudiantes llegaron tarde. (Some students arrived late - affirmative plural)
Tengo alguna idea. (I have some idea - feminine)
No tengo ningún libro. (I don't have any book - negative)
No tengo ninguna pregunta. (I don't have any question - negative feminine)
Ninguno de ellos sabe la respuesta. (None of them knows the answer - with 'de')
important: Algún usually in questions/affirmative; ningún in negatives
Both usually singular even when meaning is plural in English
Double negative OK in Spanish: No vino nadie = Nobody came
After 'sin': sin ningún problema (without any problem)

Conditional vs Future Simple.rule: FUTURE SIMPLE expresses what will happen or probability in present. CONDITIONAL expresses what would happen or probability in past. Choose based on certainty and time frame.
Conditional vs Future Simple.structure: Future: infinitive + é/ás/á/emos/éis/án | Conditional: infinitive + ía/ías/ía/íamos/íais/ían
formation: Future: infinitive + future endings (é, ás, á, emos, éis, án)
Conditional: infinitive + conditional endings (ía, ías, ía, íamos, íais, ían)
Same irregular stems for both: hacer→har-, decir→dir-, poder→podr-, etc.
uses: FUTURE: Future action (llegaré mañana), probability in present (serán las tres), promise/prediction
CONDITIONAL: Hypothetical (si tuviera tiempo, viajaría), probability in past (serían las tres), polite request, future in past
examples: Mañana llegaré temprano. (Tomorrow I will arrive early - future action)
¿Dónde estará María? (Where could María be? - probability in present, future)
Si tuviera tiempo, viajaría. (If I had time, I would travel - hypothetical, conditional)
Serían las tres cuando llegó. (It must have been three when he arrived - probability in past, conditional)
El año que viene iré a España. (Next year I'll go to Spain - future)
Dijo que vendría mañana. (He said he would come tomorrow - future in past, conditional)
important: Probability NOW: future (Estará en casa = He must be at home)
Probability THEN: conditional (Estaría en casa = He must have been at home)
Future for promises/predictions; conditional for hypotheticals and polite requests
Both have same irregular stems
